title: 109_s1120
content:
The "Hunger-Free Communities Act of 2006" includes sections on short title, findings, definitions, national commitment to end hunger, strengthening community efforts, and authorization of appropriations. The Act aims to provide collaborative grants, training, and technical assistance to create hunger-free communities. Congress finds that at the 1996 World Food Summit, the United States pledged to reduce undernourishment by half by 2015. The Department of Health and Human Services adopted the Healthy People 2010 goal to cut food insecurity in half by 2010. National nutrition programs are efficient in preventing hunger and improving nutrition. In 2001, food banks and community-based organizations helped feed millions of low-income people. The curr_chunk highlights the important roles that community organizations play in addressing hunger and food insecurity. They measure food security, develop plans for improvement, educate leaders, implement nutrition programs effectively, and connect food insecure individuals to anti-hunger programs. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to addressing hunger and food insecurity. The curr_chunk defines terms related to hunger and food security, including domestic hunger goal, emergency feeding organization, food security, and hunger-free communities goal. The curr_chunk defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture. The curr_chunk discusses the national commitment to end hunger through hunger reports. The Secretary is required to conduct a study on hunger in the United States, including data on hunger and food insecurity, measures taken by governments to address hunger goals, and potential future measures to achieve hunger-free communities. The Secretary is mandated to develop recommendations for removing obstacles to achieving domestic hunger goals and reducing domestic hunger. A report must be submitted to the President and Congress containing the results of the study on hunger in the United States and the Secretary's recommendations. TITLE II--STRENGTHENING COMMUNITY EFFORTS

SEC. 201. HUNGER-FREE COMMUNITIES COLLABORATIVE GRANTS. Title II of the document focuses on strengthening community efforts, specifically through the Hunger-Free Communities Collaborative Grants program. Eligible entities, such as public food program service providers or nonprofit organizations, can receive grants to achieve hunger-free communities goals by collaborating with local partner organizations. The Secretary can allocate up to 90% of funds for grants, with the Federal share not exceeding 80% of the costs of the activities. The non-Federal share of the cost for activities can be provided in cash or in kind, through various sources like State, local government, or private entities. To apply for a grant under this section, eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary, identifying the activities the grant will fund. To apply for a grant, eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary, detailing how the grant will be used to reduce hunger in the community. They must also list partner organizations involved and describe any necessary agreements between them. If an assessment has been done, a summary of the assessment and how the grant will help reduce hunger should be included. Priority will be given to eligible entities that demonstrate collaborative efforts to reduce hunger in their community, particularly in rural or underserved areas with high rates of food insecurity, poverty, or unemployment. Evidence of long-term efforts and public support for hunger reduction initiatives is also required. An eligible entity can use grant funds to assess hunger in the community, including analyzing the issue and evaluating facilities and equipment for achieving a hunger-free goal. An eligible entity can use grant funds for activities such as distributing food to meet the immediate needs of hungry individuals in the community. The entity must also assess the effectiveness of existing nutrition programs and emergency feeding organizations, and develop a plan to achieve hunger-free communities goals. The curr_chunk focuses on reducing hunger in the community through distributing food, providing outreach, improving access to food, developing new resources, and establishing programs for hunger-free communities. The curr_chunk focuses on establishing a program to provide food and nutrition services as part of a coordinated community-based comprehensive service. Establishing a program for hunger-free communities training and technical assistance grants. The term "eligible entity" refers to a nonprofit organization that carries out specific activities. The Secretary can allocate up to 10% of funds for grants to cover 80% of costs for these activities. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a grant. Each application submitted by an eligible entity must demonstrate non-profit status, detail training and technical assistance programs, and describe how organizations work towards domestic hunger and hunger-free communities goals. The Secretary gives priority to eligible entities serving rural or underserved areas with high rates of food insecurity, poverty, or unemployment, or those with long-term hunger reduction efforts. The eligible entity must serve a region that supports its efforts and is committed to achieving multiple hunger-free communities goals. Funds received must be used for training and technical assistance for organizations working towards domestic hunger and hunger-free communities goals. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2011, detailing grants made under the title, including activities funded and their success in achieving hunger-free communities goals. The report should also assess the overall success of activities funded by grants in achieving domestic hunger goals. Additionally, $50,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2011 to carry out title II. AN ACT to reduce hunger in the United States and for other purposes.
